list.item: IN THE LAND OF THE LIVING

div.p: 1. The current standard word for being alive is shēng 生 (ant. sǐ 死 "be dead").
2. Cún 存 (ant. wáng 亡 ) and zài 在 (ant. mò 沒 / 歿 "go under") refer to continuing in the state of being alive, but the word also refers to continued existence in general.
3. Huó 活 (ant. sǐ 死 ) specifically refers to the state of being alive when one might have been dead, and strongly connotes not only a failure to die but also the continued existence of life energy.
4. Mìng 命 refers specifically to one's life-span and not to the content of one's life that might be described in a biography.
5. Shēn 身 comes to refer to the life one conducts as in xíng shēn 行身 "conduct one's life" (Greek bios), and, and to one's lifespan as in zhōng shēn 終身 "all one's life".
6. Shòu 壽 (yāo 夭 "short life ended by an unnaturally early death") refers specifically to a lifespan as long as it naturally can be and should be.
rough draft to BEGIN TO identify synonym group members for analysis, based on CL etc. 18.11.2003. CH ／

bibl.title: A Dictionary of Selected Synonyms in the Principal Indo-European Languages

note.p: vivus refers to a living being being alive rather than dead.
animans refers to a living being being animate rather than inanimate.
vita refers to the duration of life as such, and in particular the public life.
salus refers to the safety of life.
victus refers to the private life of a man.

bibl.title: Anthologia sive Florilegium rerum et materiarum selectarum
Woerterbuch der Philosophie. Neue Beitraege zu einer Kritik der Sprache
東漢﹣隨常用詞演變研究

Handbook of Greek Synonymes, from the French of M. Alex. Pillon, Librarian of the Bibliothèque Royale , at Paris, and one of the editors of the new edition of Plaché's Dictionnaire Grec-Français, edited, with notes, by the Rev. Thomas Kerchever Arnold, M.A. Rector of Lyndon, and late fellow of Trinity College, Cambridge
A New Dictionary of Classical Greek Synonyms

sense.def: life; lifetime 沒世"to the end of his life"
avoid disastrous premature death; survive; get to survive;

entry.def: Mìng 命 refers specifically to one's life-span and not to the content of one's life that might be described in a biography.

sense.def: state of being alive, one's aliveness

entry.def: Cún 存 (ant. wáng 亡) and zài 在 (ant. mò 沒/歿 "go under") refer to continuing in the state of being alive, but the word also refers to continued existence in general.
Shòu 壽 (yāo 夭 "short life ended by an unnaturally early death") refers specifically to a lifespan as long as it naturally can be and should be.

sense.def: lifetime, span of life (long OR short)
reach the NUM age; live until NUM years

entry.def: Cún 存 (ant. wáng 亡) and zài 在 (ant. mò 沒/歿 "go under") refer to continuing in the state of being alive, but the word also refers to continued existence in general.
Huó 活 (ant. sǐ 死) specifically refers to the state of being alive when one might have been dead, and strongly connotes not only a failure to die but also the continued existence of life energy.

sense.def: allow to remain alive; cause to survive

entry.def: The current standard word for being alive is shēng 生 (ant. sǐ 死 "be dead").

sense.def: start to live, come to life, waken
life, way of life, conditions of life
one's state of being alive; one's life; one's survival; sometimes even: livelihood 治生 "look after one's livelihood"
lifespan, the stretch of time one is alive 長生
the living, those who are alive; living creatures
alive, live; living; occurring during one's lifetime
in a living state, while alive; sometimes the reference is to the object: while still alive 生燒人
be left alive; be made to survive
live in a place 生世上
cause to be a living creature; cause to survive; cause to have a good life

bibl.title: 簡明古漢語同義詞詞典

sense.def: time to enjoy life, enjoyment of life??? Cf. Greek blepein.

entry.def: Shēn 身 comes to refer to the life one conducts as in 行身 "conduct one's life" (Greek bios), and one's lifespan in certain idiomatic contexts, as in zhōng shēn 終身 "all one's life".

sense.def: life-time; personal survival; one's life as an individual (as someting one might lose, or which might be endangered)
the life of the contextually determinate N
rarely, in certain idiomatic contexts life (as something one may lose or forfeit)
fated life of men, human life
BUDDH: incarnation as a human being; human life
dwell in this world> remain alive

note.p: This expression seems to be quite late and the ZTJ might be one of the earliest sources for it (HYDCD cites the earliest examples from texts dating from the Qing period)

sense.def: living as dependent on the support/tolerance of others
former life; life in a former existence
the destiny of death [not in DCD]
life on earth; one's dying or staying alive
make a living; earn a living; earn money
life as something provided for by one's activities; life as conducted (Greek: bios rather than the zoological zooee)
life BUDDH: the cycle of life and death; SANSKRIT Saṃsāra
the cycle of death and rebirth
life; physical life on this earth; human lives; one's own life

bibl.title: 佛教語大辭典 Bukkyōgo daijiten Encyclopedic Dictionary of Buddhist Terms
A Dictionary of Chinese Buddhist Terms

note.p: Heterodox or improper ways of obtaining a living on the part of a monk, e. g. by doing work with his hands, by astrology, his wits, flattery, magic, etc. Begging, or seeking alms, was the orthodox way of obtaining a living.

sense.def: BUDDH: through heterodox means of living (often concretely refering to receiving food in an improper way (e.g. by means of work) instead of mendinancy 乞食) (see also 五邪命) (ant. of zhèngmìng 正命); skr. mithyā-ājiva; also 邪命活 pali micchājivena jīvikaṃ kappenti

BUDDH: "The five improper ways of gain or livelihood for a monk, i. e. (1) changing his appearance, e. g. theatrically; (2) advertising his own powers and virtue; (3) fortuning by physiognomy, etc.; (4) hectoring and bullying; (5) praising the generosity of another to induce the hearer to bestow presents." (SOOTHILL: 128)
exist as a living being, live
living; being of the time when sb. was alive
